column43: Does trash disposal tonnage include bulky waste?
column80: Did your municipality host comprehensive household hazardous waste collection events in 2014?
column84: Comments/Additional Information
Next Household Hazard Waste Collection is scheduled for May 30, 2015.

We offer curbside recycling and solid waste collection to 380 Central Business District commercial vendors, but we do not off trash collection to commercial vendors outside this area. We do, however, pick up recycling at commercial vendors outside the CBD if they have a recycling cart and are along the daily truck route. The CBD does not have room for individual dumpsters for each business. In the CBD trash collection is twice a week and recycling is once a week.We charge $5 for each bulk sticker. Residents are allowed one bulk sticker a week. We offer two weeks in May for residents to receive one free bulk sticker to put out a bulk item in two designated weeks in April. We offer an annual Recycling Collection Event the last Saturday of September. We collect one-use disposable bags, shoes, clothes, mercury, styrofoam, prescription medication, paper shredding, cell phones, ink cartridges, glasses and fluorescent light bulbs. We hold an annual HHW the first Saturday in June.
Link to Transfer Station webpage containing fee schedule: http://www.amherstma.gov/158/Amherst-Transfer-Station-Recycling-Cente
Section 6: 52 weeks applies to brush. Leaves and grass are 12 weeks/year. Christmas Trees until they are all gone.
All material are transported to the region refuse district in Edgartown.

Question 2- we collect almost all apartment and condo complexes, but not all. The answer choices make that difficult to communicate.Question 4- about 100 Arlington small businesses actively participate in a PAYT commercial bag program, and recycling is offered to those participants free of charge. This tonnage is included in our municipal trash and recycling numbers.Question 9- Oil-based paint is collected at HHW collection events, Latex is not collected. The answer choices make it difficult to accurately answer this question in the form.

Items indicated as collected year round are collected the 2nd & 4th Saturday of each month that the Ashby Recycle Center & Transfer Station are open. There are no tonnages for scrap metal or e-waste, as we didn't have them hauled in CY2014.

We also service private commercial haulers that provide curbside recycling and trash pickup to local residents and non-Athol residents in neighboring communities. The private haulers account for an additional 1393 tons of trash collected. A portion of the tonnage reported in question #8 is generated from the private haulers.
Household Hazardous Waste Days are held every two years. Annual town wide spring cleanup is held on the alternate years (includes recycling).
Frequently residents are referred to recycling facilities in Brockton.

Current PAYT program uses bags. Tags were originally sold and still accepted, but no longer sold. Bulky items are paid with purchased stickers that are issued in $5 segments. Stickers are applied to items based on a fee schedule posted in various locations, including the town website: http://www.ayer.ma.us/Pages/AyerMA_DPW/AyerMA_Transfer/FY15%20Transfer%20Station%20Fees.pdf
January 2015 facility introduced single stream recycling.
All yard waste is composted and used by town highway dept. mied paper is comingled with newspaper..

We collect some apartments and some condos, but not all (depends on how units were created or if they recycle - no way to answer options in that way).Oil based paint collected once a year, latex paint collected weekly (if dry).
Households with senior citizens receive 40 free 30gallon stickers per year. These are the only residents who receive this PAYT benefit.

Public Works collects trash and recyclables from Boston Fire Houses as well as Boston Public Libraries. They also collect recyclables from Boston Public Schools and some municipal buildings.The revenue/cost per ton value changes on a month to month basis, depending on the commodity price given to the city by the processor..

Our facility is an Enterprise Fund and does not use real estate taxes to fund its operations. There is an annual sticker for the recycling center, but that does not cover the cost of curbside collection, nor is it adequate to cover costs for the recycling center. I therefore said fees fund our program, but that is only a tiny fraction of our revenue. Gate fees are our main source of revenue. The recycling center fees are $30 for a sticker with $20 for seniors and $10 for a replacement sticker. Plus, there are fees for certain items once an allotment of free bulky items stickers are used. More information can be found on our web page at townofbourne.com.We do accept recyclables from businesses and some condos we pick up from, but MSW is limited to the town of Falmouth through their contract with us for their residential curbside collection program. Therefore, as we have switched to accepting almost all municipal waste combustor ash, and don't take commercial hauler business MSW anymore, the listing under the Municipal program has changed. We also take MSW from our own curbside collection program. The number of households has been refined to reflect the small amount of multi-family units we collect from and a trailer park as of the date of the attached form. Our paint shed is open seasonally from April - May on Fridays and Saturdays. Bulky waste and MSW are disposed of in our landfill at no charge..

Polystyrene is placed in the solid waste containers.We do not accept yard waste at all.Our rigid plastics, wood, mattresses, and carpet are not separately tracked.We pay .07 cents for each monitor. Of the 12 tons of e-waste, a quantity of 2677 monitors were collected.Of the 64 tons of metal/appliances, 57 tons were scrap metal. We received an average of $50 per ton rebated on hauling fees.
Boxford residents can drop off yard waste in the contiguous town of Topsfield with the payment of $5 composting fee per drop for 30 weeks a year.
Boylston is part of the Wachusett Earth Day Recycling Center.We are a private subscription community.

Our paint recycling is actually 8 months. We close our paint shed in Nov. depending on temps and re-open in April.Mixed glass cost to the Town was $4,722.75 (188.91 tons0Wood tonnage/cost includes carpet and mattresses

Curbside Trash and Recycling collected from 1-5 family units (not 6). Paint collected 6 days per week from April 1 thru October 31 at Recycle Center. Recycle center open to all residents and businesses. Trash program---1'st 32 gallon barrel or bag, 1 bulky item, 1 appliance, unlimited recycling & yard waste per week included in trash fee. Any additional trash must be placed in PAYT bags.

Tons of bulky rigid plastic is included in curbside single stream and commingle drop-off. Textiles collected from several organizations with drop-off boxes located throughout the city, and thrift stores - all of which report tons to us upon request.

Charlemont and Shelburne share a transfer station site but have separate trash and recycling systems. They share 2 Salvation Army boxes. All tonnage is being reported on Charlemont's survey because they own the site but some of the textile/book tonnage is from Shelburne residents.
All material is delivered to the MV Refuse District in Edgartown for processing and packing prior to shipping off Island.
Clarksburg holds an annual bulky waste/electronics collection.
Town operated a collection program for leaves from residential properties on five (5) Saturdays in the Fall, but no tonnage information is available for the material collected.
Conway has a robust clothing reuse shed but does not have tonnage data because clothing is redistributed to residents using the transfer station.
The numbers for eWaste only include numbers from 1 event. I'm still waiting on numbers from the vendor, so those totals are likely to double.

The Town of Dartmouth does contract with a private contractor to pick up solid waste in some municipal buildings. Recycling pick up id done by the town. Street Sweepings (1,135.71 tons) this is not counted as solid waste because the district reuses this material for cover.

In addition to Household Hazardous Waste Collection, the Sustainability Advisory Committee in partnership with the DPW and Environmental Department hosted 2 recycling events. The October event coincides with the Board of Health's Household Hazardous Waste event and invited Shred-It to recycle paper and Refoamit to recycle Styrofoam, as well as Scrap-it for metal, TV and electronic recycling and textile recycling. For the past 3 years the Town has held a styrofoam collection event the first Saturday after Christmas. This past year we include electronics as well. The Committee has decided in 2015 and going forward to host 2 events/year - one in the spring and one in the fall and to discontinue the December event. In the future we would like to hold a recycling event in the Spring and Fall. The one in the Spring would be around Earth Day and the Fall event would coincide with Household Hazardous Waste Day. We will also continue to hold the December holiday styrofoam collection event.
Deerfield has a Red Cross drop-box for clothing and books. A tonnage number was not available. The town also accepts yard waste and brush but does not have an estimate of tonnage to report.

4. One pre-school participates in program; the high school does not.8. Cardboard includes mixed paper and news8. Not all textile vendors pay revenue8. Bulky rigid plastics are included in container collection8. Scrap metal, electronics and yard waste total not available
The number of households served in the municipal trash and recycling programs includes condominiums (of varying sizes) that choose to participate in the municipal program.
we take used books about 3 Tons per yer for Discovery Books

Number of households served was determined by the number of first transfer station stickers sold. Eastham has many seasonal residnets which will stay part of the summer and pay a $10 entry fee as needed.
Erving collects yard waste and brush at the highway garage but does not have a tonnage calculation.

All residential units have access to municipal collection. Not all use and some supplement once a week municipal collection.Small businesses are also eligible for curbside collection. white goods and ewaste tonnage is not tracked

For MSW the town does pick-up a few small "Mom & Pop" businesses because they have always been picked-up. New businesses are not allowed to be collected, private haulers are hired. Recycled goods are picked-up if anyone places them curbside. Some condo's do not offer recycling and those residents use the town curbside service by leaving the goods on the curb because the hauler will not enter "private property". There was no space to detail how curbside recycling is paid: contract for pick-up and hauling to recycling facilities is paid from tax base. In March 2015 we will move to the two-cart system and we are very hopeful the recycling rate will greatly increase and the MSW will decrease. We currently use the antiquated 18 gallon recycle bins.

In Section 5, it asks if we collect bulky waste through our municipal contract. We do not, however; we collect it at our Waste Management Facility, but it is not weighed or otherwise tracked at this point. We will be implementing a bulky waste collection program at this Facility in the very near future.
yard waste does not include community drop-off locationBook Recycling not included

I gave the answer on latex paints that is closest to our program, but we are not truly year round. We close the paint shed from November to April. We have a Salvation Army box for textiles, but we do not collect any tonnage information, so I left that item blank. In addition to medical sharps, we do year round collection of expired and unwanted medications, and sharps and medications are collected anonymously, so it is a resource open to all, not just residents. We are part of the MPHN [Montachusett Public Health Network] a Public Health District Incentive Grant district, and all 11 members of our communities have medication and sharps collection.

The cost is $2.50 per 30 gallon bag, with punch cards costing $75.00 each. The PAYT program collects enough money to cover our costs, but we appropriate in our budget the amount we believe we will collect in PAYT payments instead of setting up a revolving fund. To dump waste at our transfer station one must purchase a punch card to do so. Any town resident can use our transfer station to dispose of the recycling items as long as they can show proof of residency. We don't sell or provide residents with TS stickers. We are so small we know everyone in town.
Yes we accept items year round Monday through Friday.
We received 2 rebate checks a year for paper and containers. Total rebate for the year was $3,222.79

CRTR, Inc. is our e-waste hauling/processing vendor and does not provide a tonnage amount. They provide us with the total number of items received per haul. In 2014 we took in 292 e-waste items. They charge $800.00 per haul (3 - 4 times per year).E.L. Harvey & Sons, Inc. is our mixed paper, commingle, glass & scrap metal hauling/processing vendor. All items have a hauling fee of $180.00. The tonnage per haul varies. We receive a credit of $35.00/ton of mixed paper, $0 for commingle, $125.00 credit for scrap metal and are charged $35.00/ton of glass. We hold 2 bulk waste events per year. E.L. Harvey & Sons, Inc is our vendor for hauling/processing. They charge $630.00/40 yrd container up to 4.75 tons. If over 4.75 tons/per container an additional amount would be charged. We have not exceeded that amount per event.
We have combined many of our Waste Ban recyclable items under the wood catagory

Passenger Tires - 10.5 tons. Yard Waste - Leaves and Grass clippings for the season totaled 7,072 yards (drop-off and curbside). Calculation - 533lbs per yard = 1,884.68 tons. Leaves and Grass cost the City $175 per load. Wood Chips from Brush totaled 780 tons. The City does not currently incur any expense or gain any revenue from the disposal of brush.
#4b does not actually apply.

The Town of Holden pays a fixed monthly bill to casella which includes trash and recycling pick-up and the disposal of 150 tons of recycling, if they go over this amount on a per monthly basis, they get a "recycling bonus" for $64 per ton (our tipping fee)
The Town of Huntington converted to single stream recycling in the fall of 2014.

Our recycling committee holds three events annually to collect Styrofoam (free dropoff for residents) and electronics (net proceeds go to town nonprofit organizations). We also offer free recycling at our transfer station of the following items: waste cooking oil, fluorescent and CFL bulbs, and boat shrink wrap (from April to July). Ipswich also has a pilot curbside composting program with 460 participants who pay for the program (approximately 8% of the households in town).
LANESBOROUGH HOLDS AN ANNUAL BULKY/ELECTRONICS COLLECTION.

All of Lenox's recycling and refuse collection, including all residential, all municipal/schools, is contracted through private haulers. In the future, you may wish to provide a box at the bottom of page one for "wash hands" municipalities. Thank you.
#4b does not actually apply. #10: Greenfield allows Leyden residents to use their permanent HHW site open 5 days/week with an appointment.

The Town of Lunenburg is a member of the Devens HHW which is open 20 times a year and collects many of the other recycled material not collected at the curb. The town is also next to the Town of Townsend which has a drop off center that allows non-residents, is open twice a month and accepts most of the other recycled material not collected at the curb or at Devens. The town is also a member of Nashoba Boards of Health which collects sharps year round. Bulky tonnage is calculated based on items collected at curb and multiplied by weight on moving company weight tables.
The data represents 11 months under a contract that ended November 30, 2014, and one month of data under the new contract that began December 1, 2014.

Hazardous Products Collection sponsored by CMW District. Scrap Metal/White Goods, C&D Materials, Swap Shop or Book Re-Use by CMW District #8 (other recycled material) scrap metal/white goods and e-waste - CMW District. Medical Waste/Sharps - Board of Health Recycling Tonnage - cardboard, steel/tin cans, glass, plastic, newspaper - included in single stream. Bulky waste is accepted at the CMWRRDD Transfer Station. They would be responsible for tracking the tonnage collected.
We have been hosting our Hazardous Waste day collection with the town of Hudson in Marlborough, MA the past several years

We play a per cart rate for recycling disposal, and a per cart and per dumpster rate for trash removal, in addition to the fee per ton for trash removal. We pay per ton for yard waste disposal as well as a per collection fee, unfortunately the 2014 tonnage wasn't available at the time of the filing of this report.

1. In July 2014 we began our automated single stream recycling cart collection program which has increased our recycling rate by around 3-5% each month. 2. Our Ewaste is collected with all white goods, freon and CRT items so the total includes all of these type of items. We also pay a flat rate of $900 a month for collection so we do not have a per ton unit price and so I left the cost at $0.3. We have a Planet Aid textile collection container at our recycling center year round, however it is a private company not managed by us so i did not include anything in textile questions.

Mattresses - Melrose partnered with United Teen Equality Center for a once per event and UTEC charged Melrose $10 but Melrose didn't charge the residents.Rigid plastics - Melrose hosts a once per year collection event and JRM takes the rigid plastic material to be recycled.E-waste - Melrose paid 15 cents per pound of CRTs and received a rebate of 3 cents per pound of other e-waste including printers, home electronics etc.).Recycling program changed September 8. JRM started collecting single stream weekly recycling and keeping the rebate on that material. Melrose received a rebate from JRM for the material collected at Melrose's Recycling Drop-Off Center. At the Center, recyclables are separated into: cardboard, commingles and paper. Because Melrose switched from collecting recycling in house to having a hauler collect, some of the revenue/costs changed throughout the year therefore I just entered the average revenue/cost.

The number of households served by the municipal recycling program includes those condominium complexes that chose to join the City's program while DEP's Municipal Recycling Incentive Program (MRIP) was available.

The town currently provides weekly curbside trash pickup and bi-weekly recycling for residents who sign up for the service. There are two payment systems in town- one being a quarterly payment of $51.00 and the other being a PAYT sticker program.The town is changing to automated pick up in July 2015. At that point residents will be given a 96 gallon recycling container no matter which program they are part of. The residents on the quarterly payment system will receive a 64 gallon trash container while residents on stickers will be switched to bags and will receive a 32 gallon trash container. The town received the SMRP grant in 2014 for recycling bins and SMART/PAYT start up.Middleborough is also a South Shore Recycling Coop member town. As part of this membership town residents can participate in any other member towns Hazardous waste day as long as the residents has authorization from there town.The town's transfer station is operated by Waste Management. We deliver all collected recyclables to the transfer station they are then delivered by WM to their MIRF. We do not receive any payment/revenue for the materials.
Montague collects yard waste and brush but does not have tonnage figures.

The single stream automated cart program began on June 23, 2014.Single unit buildings received 65-gallon carts, multiple unit buildings received 95-gallon carts.Other materials recycled:Antifreeze: 0.66 tonsBulky Waste (Recycled at New Bedford Waste Services): 492 tonsC&D (Recycled at New Bedford Waste Services): 67.53 tonsCooking Oil: 2.75 tonsMercury Items: 3.00 tonsMotor Oil: 7.88 tonsOil Filters: 0.9 tonsStyrofoam: 1.06 tonsTires: 19.85 tons

Recycling is enforced for nonprofits because they cannot purchase a trash cart without also purchasing a recycling cart. We do collect hazardous wastes including chemicals, acid, plant foods, photography equipment, etc.
Dried out latex paint cans are accepted year round while oil based paints are only accepted at our annual HHW event.

RE: #6 (Yard Waste/Xmas Tree Collection), in addition to the yard waste drop off listed, Northampton holds Xmas Tree collections on two consecutive Saturdays in January. These collections are free and open to the public (transfer station permit not required).Re: #8 (Recycled/Composted Tonnage):1) Our clean wood collection program began in April, 2015. No 2014 tonnage data is available.2) Revenue/cost per ton data for mixed paper, co-mingled containers, bulky rigid plastic, scrap metal, and E-waste does NOT include transport & labor costs.3) Revenue/cost per ton data for food waste includes transport, labor, equipment & supplies costs.

1)There is a private hauler licensed to collect trash and recycling in Northborough with about 927 customers, but their customers can also use town bags if they choose to. 2) The Town only holds one HHWD event per year as a result of a severe drop in participation once a $10 per box fee was implemented in 2005. 3) The trash and recycling tonnage reported above does not include school amounts because the School Department hired a separate contractor to collect trash and recycling as of July 1, 2011. 4) The amount of yard waste disposed of in 2014 was higher than most years as the DPW cleaned out an area containing yard waste accumulated over several years and now plans to remove all yard waste collected each year. 5) The town offered all condominiums the opportunity to join the program when it started in 2003 but only some have joined.

3. Municipal Recycling Program: Please note that the Municipal Recycling Program is a DROP-OFF program and it is unknown as to which properties (single family, multi-family, condos, apartments) take advantage of the Drop-Off center.4. Northbridge does not have a solid waste program other than the regional drop-off recycling center which is available to municipal buildings, schools, businesses, and non-residents. Under B the questionnaire request an answer as to "funding source" - there is NO FEE/FUNDING SOURCE - please note that this response of "property tax" is NOT APPLICABLE but a response was REQUIRED.5. Solid Waste Collection: Please note that the response under A. was ZERO but responses were required under B, C, & D - these responses are NOT APPLICABLE to the Town of Northbridge - response only provided as this was a REQUIRED FIELD.
Under scrap metals of the total 285T (curbside pick up WM) 84 T was dropped off. The 84 T of scrap metals generated $13,725. Revenue applies only to 84T under the scrap metals.

Glass container only are recycled at a cost to townUnable to develop tonnage for carpets. Carpets are collected by item and mixed with Bulky waste 160 pieces of carpet were collected for a revenue of $1,600. Currently we have a demo/bulky waste tipping fee of $90/tonWe do not track wood collections separately. Wood is considered in Demo/bulky waste tonnagesScrap Metal/Large Appliances does not contain Freon containing appliances. These are handled separately from non-Freon containing appliancesEWaste is recorded per unit: CM 181,TV: 717, Other: 75. Total Revenue $5,112
The Town of Paxton is a member of the Wachusett Watershed Regional Recycle Center that provides recycling for hazardous products,chemical, paints, household items, electronics, tires etc.

All paper, news, OCC and mixed paper are combined. Some rigid plastics are included in containers. Recyclables are charged by the haul not ton; no revenue. Some material is taken at other locations in town such as the Town Barn for waste oil.

The Town of Plainfield does not have a website. Community events are shared through a local town newsletter and posted throughout the community - town offices, churches, post office, businesses, and the transfer station.Information concerning Transfer Station Fees and Household Hazardous Waste Collection events are additionally hosted on the HRMC website.The HRMC representative for the Town frequently submits recycling news in the Town newsletter.

out of the 3641 households in Plainville 1826 are on the municipal collection program, it is therefore assumed that 1815 have private collection. Out of the 1815 that have private collection, it has been confirmed that 814 have recycling service. Either recycling carts or recycling only dumpsters are located on the multi unit properties.
Municipal Program Annual Fees:$170 / Curbside Service$90 / Transfer Station Access$260 / Both Curbside Service & Transfer Station Access$10 / Recycle Only Sticker for the Transfer Station
Drop off recycling available at Wachusett Watershed Regional Recycling Center.
Rowe's reuse shed includes clothing that is redistributed to residents using the transfer station. There is no tonnage estimate.
Private subscription community and a member of Wachusett.
On the condos question; we service a total of 1,600 condos. Some are very large complexes; some are not. The current question does not allow for this answer.

Savoy held its annual bulky waste day in October 2014 on a day of torrential rains! A small turnout and so the electronics container did not come anywhere near full and has been at the Transfer Station since, slowing collecting. That electronics tonnage will be reported in 2015.

If a household already has a Transfer Station sticker they are allowed one Bulky Waste coupon free of charge. If a household does not have a Transfer Station sticker they are charged $25 for a Bulky Waste coupon.

Charlemont and Shelburne share a transfer station site but have separate trash and recycling systems. They share 2 Salvation Army boxes. All tonnage is being reported on Charlemont's survey because they own the site but some of the textile/book tonnage is from Shelburne residents.

Scrap metal revenue ranged from $135/load to $200/load, so I simply counted the number of loads and added the revenue received and divided the revenue by the number of loads to get an average.Our food waste is picked up by a company that charges by the month for providing 4-64 gallon toters. I simply divided the monthly charge by the number of gallons we collect to get the charge per ton. We estimate our food waste weighs 7 pounds per gallon because it is quite wet.For the Electronics cost per ton, because only CRT's and laptops are charged and all other mixed E-waste is not, I simply added up all the charges and divided the total by the total tons of all the electronics collected (whether there was a charge for them or not) in order to derive a cost per ton of all electronics.
We are a member of Devens Hazardous Waste
The $68.00 per Ton disposal fee does not include the hauling fee ($80.00 per load) nor the fuel surcharge that Wickles charges (typically $27.20 per load) for trucking.

The Transfer Station is open to any residential household that purchases a permit regardless of the type of housing they live in. We do not service condominium complexes or apartment complexes in bulk, however, the individual units can purchase a permit. The number that we report as households serviced is just the number of households that purchased a permit, not the number of households that could purchase a permit.
I cannot answer section 4b. Our trash is funded through contract with Casella/SRD and is reimbursed. I did mark it so that I could submit it.
Medical waste/sharps collected at Board of Health office in Town Hall.
Changed recycling to single stream 7/1/2014
#4b doesn't actually apply
NEDT has a collection site open to the public that is in Sutton.
If communities share a sight for HHWD and share costs it should not matter where the event is held.

White Goods/Scrap Metal/Appliances are collected bi-weekly. Residents pay $10.00 for a tag for each item. The Town paid the Trash Collection Company $9.18 for each item picked up.Swansea conducts a Household Hazardous Waste Day every other year in April. The next collection will be in April 2015.Mattresses, Carpet and other 'Bulky Items' are pickup up with the 'Trash' on a weekly basis. Residents affix one tag per item at a cost to themselves. The Town pays the contractor effectively $73.51 per ton for these items

For trash and recycle households served, some of the condos and apartments in the five to six unit range, seven to eight unit range, and nine and above range are collected as part of the municipal program, but not all.
We have about 12 condos association in Town and some of the condos do receive trash and recycling service through the Town.
The Clerk for the Assessors office is not in today, so I will forward her information to you upon her return.
Compost Program. Waltham residents may purchase compost bins on state contract at the Lexington DPW. Waltham promotes composting.

The Town of Wareham is contracted with a private trash hauler for muncipal buildings for trash and recyclables. If offers nothing for residents except the following:1) The town has a recycling drop-off center which is currently funded by a grant from the estate of a private party. In addition to the routine recycling items, the center handles paint (both latex&oil based), tires, lead core and re-chargeable batteries, fluorescent bulbs, other mercury bearing items, including thermostats and thermometers. In addition the center takes old flags, white metal goods, misc. metal of all types and electronics. It is estimated that the private grant will be exhausted by the end of 2015 and the center will have to shut down. In addition, the recycling focus will be lost for the Town of Wareham.2. The Town of Wareham participates in the Carver-Marion-Wareham Regional Refuse Disposal District. This provides residents with two transfer facilities for trash and some recyclables disposal. These are both located out of the town of Wareham. A sticker is required for residents to utilize these facilities.
These statistics are for 2014

Wendell accepts scrap metal and white goods but has a company that takes it for free thus there are no weights for their material. The Towns website shows the materials are accepted:http://www.wendellmass.us/index.php/governance/services/wrats.html

The company we contract with to run our transfer station (E.L. Harvey & Sons) does not weigh the recyclables they collect from residents as part of our contract. They do collect them, but they are just combined with recycling materials Harvey's accepts through other contracts with other entities. The transfer station is staffed by a Harvey's employee at all times it is open. The employee checks transfer station stickers and enforces the mandatory recycling ban.

NEDT Household Hazardous Waste Collection facility opened in Westfield in 2014. Residents bring material to this location for disposal. The City of Westfield is currently working with NEDT to establish a program that will allow the city to subsidize the cost for residents using this facility.The City does accept leaves and grass clippings from residents at our Transfer Station. Due to the fact that the material is processed on site there is no way for us to determine the actual tonnage.

yard waste (brush, not leaves) is accepted at a drop-off facility on 2 collection dates during 2014. The Fire Dept picks up Christmas trees one weekend after Christmas. Residents pay a fee. This is coordinated completely by the Fire Dept. Household Hazardous Waste collections are done every other year. We inform residents that Lexington has events once per month that they may attend on a fee basis.

>The use of the Transfer Station is eligible to all residents, businesses, schools of Westport and other surrounding communities. We do not restrict anyone except commercial haulers. As long as they have purchased the sticker they are able to use the facility. Most likely it is only SF, 2F, Mobile homes and multi-house and some small businesses. All others most likely use dumpsters.>We do not participate in single stream. All Metal is 96.14 tons/$150.00; Plastic (non rigid) is 19.27 tons/$20; Glass is 97.20 tons/(-$25.00).>We do not track wood and carpet separately and pay $69.50/ton. We do not take in C&D only some household clean wood.>Westport did not have HHW event and haven't since 2009. All Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut residents are able to use the NEDT facility in Sutton, MA year round for which we provide flyers with the facilities information to our customers.>We only take in Xmas tress for one month out of the year and we do not accept any other type of brush items.
17,500 households=2,500 condominium +15,000 HH curbside. Trash tons averaged 20,000/year. W/carts, CY2014 trash tons = 15,745 tons. Recy CY2014 = 5,153 tons vs. history 3,050 tons/year.
Whately's food waste is transported by the town to a local composting operation that does not charge the town for tipping.
Town has a mattress recycling collection in place and is offering access to other HRMC member towns at a cost of $25 per mattress (any size).
We collect hazardous waste such as paint, antifreeze, used oil, etc. every day the transfer station is open. Large appliances and e waste are combined cost
Residents can use the Minuteman Hazardous Waste Facility in Lexington on a pay per use basis. They could also use Clean Harbors in Braintree, MA.

Wasn't sure what to check for #9, Collection Frequency. Worcester's drop off center is open from April through November and some items such as auto batteries, auto tires, televisions are collected during April - November so it doesn't fit in any of the categories you have listed.

Anyone, business or resident, in the Town of Yarmouth may utilize the various recycling services offered at the Disposal Area.Our swap shop is currently closed due to the volunteers violating building codes. We hope to have it reopened soon.
